ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: some knowledge about psychoanalysis, dreams/reality, Freud
First learned philosophy. It was a brand new experience for me to analyze dreams.

lots of things including how to interpret my dreams, how to distinguish between reality and dream, theories of Freud and Descartes ... Besides i could also get to know some of writing techniques, how to read articles easily and effectively, way to analyze the films and so on. This course helped me to enhance diverse skills
Thinking in philosophically, knowledge about dreams and relevant psychologists and philosophers.

I learnt how to critically observe text and film for hidden meanings and learning outcomes or morals, which has helped in not only my observational skills, but writing skills. This course was insightful, and I learnt many philosophical viewpoints which were critical in personal development.
Gained a general understanding of Freudian theory and related criticisms; acquired a way of thinking about dream-related issues
I gained a lot of theoretical knowledge about dreams.
How to understand dreams, from analysis of the context to the systems that make them up

Philosophical, and text evaluations with a lot of critical thinking skills involved. This discipline is however not suited to my natural inclinations, since I have omitted studying any humanities subject for over a year at my high school already. I did not see myself enjoying the class 90% of the times, as I found the subject to be too abstract, combining ideas from a wide array of disciplines with no solid foundation. I initially thought that this would delve into the scientific explanation of dreams, and its implications but to my surprise, it combines various historical philosophical texts even inclusive of the Old Torah! I do not see myself pursuing a discipline along this line in college, unless it is one of my pre-requisites for graduate studies. The breadth of this course is also astonishing, inclusive of films, humanities texts and even a slight touch on the psychological explanations of dreams. (which is what I was expecting) It is interesting nonetheless to be able to explore a wide array of disciplines which American colleges do offer unakin to the British universities which required students to declare a professional career in which they wanted to pursue at the age of 17. Nonetheless, it would have been a lot easier to me to have taken a natural science course I enjoy such as Chemistry, which would have allowed me to score an A.

"The Logic of Dreams" equipped me with a deeper understanding of fundamental psychological concepts and provided me with a basic knowledge of other relevant topics. This courses heavily enhanced my close reading and annotation skills, and gave me a desire to ask questions about seemingly mundane or trivial entities.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: tooo many materials
Little bit hard to understand in English in both lecture and TA class

+) making concepts thru conversation between students and prof. / active TA session which helps a lot to further understand and follow the class 

-) if one didn't read the texts before class, one couldn't be able to attend class. and the thing is the amount of literary are enormous which is quite difficult for non-native speakers. i guess narrowing down of the reading parts is needed
Strength: practice our own thinking.  No weakness
None.

The core issues that the course focuses on are more interesting, and the research questions that the course poses on this are illuminating. However, the course could perhaps have organized the content in a more holistic, planned way and increased the coverage of specific intellectual issues.
We had a lot of in-class discussions, which helped me better understand what I have read for assignments.

It is a bit too early for a dream class, which I prefer to not disturb my dreams taking. 
However the class material is quite interesting and very engaging. I love my professor and my TAs.

Professor North and my TA are willing to explain texts in which students could not understand. 
One complain is however was that the course was held in one of the humanities quadrangle room, with table arrangements similar to my primary school class. Taking into consideration that this is a humanities subject, discussions and opinion sharing must be facilitated. The classroom in which the class is held is more like a Physics or Chemistry class, similar to when I was learning Newton's Third Law in my 6th Grade class in a Thai primary school. 
The nature of this subject is based upon discussions and sharing opinions, classrooms like that in Watson Center would not help students achieved the purpose of studying this course. 
I also believe that there should be a warning for future prospect students that this is purely a humanities course, and that the students would not delve into the scientific explanations behind dreams, rather an abstract knowledge spanning many philosophical texts and even the Torah or the Spanish literature which I was not at all expecting.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: yes, if they are interested in dreams

If you are interested in dreams, then I would say yes. Writing Dream Journal everyday is a part of fun, and interpreting my dream with the knowledge that I learned during the session is also a big fun. Even though I had quite a difficult time to prepare for this course every two days, I strongly recommend you to take this course. But what you have to keep in mind is that when you participate actively, like the discussion, small play or sharing dreams, the class would be more full of joy.
Yes.
Yes. The readings were great, and different from the usual. It exposed me to different philosophical viewpoints and helped me in my personal philosophical development.

I would probably recommend this course to others. Even though the class didn't fit my points of interest very well, the instructor's commitment and reasonable amount of workloads made the course advantageous.
For students who want to study dreams from a theoretical perspective rather than a symbolic one, this is the course for them!

I would recommend this course to those whose academic interests are deeply vested in the humanities, especially for English Literature or Religious Studies students. If you enjoy the areas of natural sciences however, you would not have enjoyed this subject, and could found yourself trying to stay awake while trying to interpret the philosophers' implications.

Absolutely. This course provides a much needed equilibrium between work and play, and allows students to explore their own psyche while improving their academics. The workload is similar to that of any college-level course, yet the assigned material is engaging and holistically relevant to class discussions.

narratives.question_text: How will you use the knowledge and skills you learned in this course in your future endeavors?
comments: Reading lots of reading materials which made me think better.

My fear of reading English books was erased clearly thanks to this course. It still takes a long time to read it, but i am willing to read English books. Also the writing skills I have learned during this course would help me a lot when I compose any college level essay
I have improved greatly in my writing and comprehension of difficult texts. The texts were thought provoking and helped me in my personal philosophical development.
I will use the knowledge of dreams every time I study dreams in literary and cinematic works in the future.

Critical Thinking and Analytical skills are two of the most important skills I have garnered from this course. In the future, in completion of my humanities subject pre-requisites for graduate schools, the reading skills and interpretation skills are two of the most important skills I have garnered. It also made me realize that I perhaps shouldn't take Philosophy as one of my double major, in spite of how cool the subject sounds.

extras.title: GMAN S190 01/HUMS S221 01/LITR S311 01 - The Logic of Dreams
